block.p: Re ''Brat Control on Easy Street'' (news article, June 12):
Re ''Brat Control on Easy Street'' (news article, June 12):
I offer this advice for parents with young children: Start them immediately on the ''jar system,'' an idea first introduced in the early 1990's by Neale S. Godfrey, the kids-and-money guru.
Each week, children work around the house to earn an allowance that is then divided into different jars.
In our home, those jars are for College, Charity, Saving for Fun Stuff, Quick Cash (pocket money) and Tax.

Our son is 9 and has been using the jars for five years. He has made several small but well-considered charitable contributions to various organizations, and has bought toys that he saved many weeks or months to buy.

We still buy him birthday and Christmas presents and, yes, even the occasional gift for no reason. But there is nothing like seeing one's child buy a $50 Pokemon Nintendo game with $1 bills and coins that he earned and saved, and sharing the sense of accomplishment he feels.
ALICE C. WALSH Carmel, N.Y., June 12, 2000
